The spring is on the south side of the road, the cliff is several zhang high, and the water comes out from the middle.
It is said that there were hundreds of merchants who ran out of water on the way, and they were exhausted and did not know what to do when they got here.
At that time, there was a monk among the group who did not bring any travel funds and relied on the group to beg for a living.
The group discussed and said:
This monk serves the Buddha, so we provide for him. Even if we travel thousands of miles, he does not bring anything.
Now we are suffering, but he does not worry at all. We should go and tell him.
The monk said:ğŸ”½You are all suffering, and I am also suffering. You are all thirsty, and I am also thirsty. I do not know what to do.

As the crowd was in a perilous and difficult situation, they all followed his instructions.
After receiving the precepts, the monk said:
After I climb the cliff, you should call out 'Father, please give me water' and say it as many times as you need.
Shortly after he left, the crowd, as instructed, made the request, and soon water flowed down, providing enough for everyone, to the delight of the entire group.
The teacher did not return, and when the crowd went to look, he had already passed away.
Everyone, young and old, wept in grief, and cremated him according to the Western Regions' method.
At the place where he sat, they gathered bricks and stones to build a stupa, which is still there today, and the water has never dried up.
Depending on the number of travelers coming and going, the water is either fine or coarse;
if there are no people, it is just a trickle.
The Dharma Master stayed with the group by the spring.
At dawn, they passed another silver mountain.
The mountain was very high and wide, all of it silver ore, from which the silver coins of the Western Regions were produced.
To the west of the mountain, they encountered a group of bandits, who took their belongings and left.

At that time, dozens of merchant Hu people who were traveling with them greedily wanted to trade first, so they secretly left in the middle of the night. After going more than ten li, they encountered bandits who robbed and killed them, with not a single survivor.
When the Dharma Master arrived, he saw their remains and had no more belongings, deeply saddened.
Gradually moving on, they saw the royal capital in the distance. King Agnidatta and his ministers came to welcome them and invited them to stay for offerings.
The country had previously been disturbed by Gaochang invaders and harbored resentment, so they were unwilling to provide horses.

The next day, the king invited him to the palace and made extensive offerings, but the food had the three purities, which the Dharma Master did not accept, and the king was deeply puzzled.

Two days' journey to the west, he encountered more than two thousand Turkic bandits. The mountain is steep and lofty, reaching to the heavens.

Since the opening of the world, ice and snow have accumulated here, forming glaciers that do not melt in spring and summer. They are covered with mist and clouds, and looking up at them, one cannot see their end.
The fallen peaks and glaciers that block the path are sometimes hundreds of feet high and several dozen feet wide. Because of this, the path is winding and dangerous, and climbing it is difficult.
Moreover, wind and snow swirl together, and even with double boots and heavy fur coats, one cannot help but shiver with cold.
When one wants to sleep or eat, there is no dry place to stop. One can only hang a pot to cook and sleep on the ice.
After seven days, one finally leaves the mountain. Among the companions, one out of every three or four who freeze to death, and the oxen and horses are even worse.
After leaving the mountain, one arrives at a clear pool, which is also called the Hot Sea.

Seeing that the water does not freeze even in the face of towering mountains, it got its name. The water may not necessarily be warm. It is about 1,400 to 500 li in circumference, long from east to west and narrow from south to north. Looking at it, it seems vast, without waiting for a gust of wind to create huge waves several dozen feet high.
Going northwest along the sea for more than 500 li, I reached the city of Suye, where I encountered the Yabghu Khan of the Tujue, who was out hunting at the time, with a great many war horses.
The Khan was wearing a green silk robe, his hair was loose, and a ten-foot-long silk cloth was wrapped around his forehead and hung down behind.
More than 200 officials, all in brocade robes with braided hair, surrounded him on the left and right.
The rest of the troops were all in fur and felt coats, with spears and bows, and horsemen on camels and horses, as far as the eye could see, with no end in sight.
After meeting him, the Khan was delighted and said:
I'm going out for a while, and I'll be back in two or three days. You can go to the camp first.
He ordered an official named Damashi to escort and accommodate me.
After three days in the camp, the Khan returned and invited the Dharma Master in.
The Khan resided in a large tent decorated with golden flowers, dazzling to the eyes.
The officials were seated in two rows in front of a long table, all in brocade robes, the rest of the guards standing behind.
Even the lord of the Qionglu tent would be considered honorable and beautiful.
More than thirty steps away from the tent, the Khan came out to greet and bow to the Dharma Master, and after exchanging greetings, he entered and sat down.
The Turks worship fire and do not use beds, as wood contains fire, so they respect it and do not sit on it, but only on heavy cushions on the ground.
For the Dharma Master, they set up an iron folding chair with cushions, inviting him to sit.
After a while, they led the Chinese envoy and the Gaochang envoy in to present the official letters and gifts. The Khan looked at them himself and was very pleased, ordering the envoys to sit down.

After the meal, grape juice was served again, and they requested the Dharma teacher to speak on the Dharma.

The Dharma teacher then taught the ten wholesome deeds, the nurturing of life, and the practices leading to liberation through the perfections, and they raised their hands to their foreheads in joy and accepted it with faith.
He stayed there for several days, and they urged him to stay, saying:
The teacher need not go to India. That land is very hot, and in the tenth month it is like the fifth month here. Seeing the teacher's appearance, I fear he will melt there.
Those people are dark-skinned and have no proper deportment, so they are not worth seeing.
The Dharma Master replied:

The Khan then ordered the army to find someone who could understand Chinese and the languages of various countries. Going west from here for more than 400 li, we reach Pingyu, also called Qianquan (Thousand Springs). The area is several hundred li square, with many ponds and abundant exotic trees. It is cool and refreshing, a place to escape the summer heat.

The king and the people did not believe in Buddhism, and took fire worship as their way.
There were two temples, but no monks lived in them. If guest monks came, the Hu people would burn them with fire and chase them away, not allowing them to stay.
When the Dharma Master first arrived, the king still treated him with arrogance.
After spending the night, he expounded the causes and effects of humans and gods for him, praised the merits of the Buddha, and the blessings and benefits of reverence.
The king was delighted and invited him to receive the precepts, and eventually became sincere.
The two young monks he brought with him went to the temple to pay homage, and the Hu people again burned them with fire and chased them away.

The novice monks returned and reported this to the king. When the king heard about it, he ordered the capture of the burners. After capturing them, he assembled the people and ordered the cutting off of their hands.
The Dharma Master was about to encourage goodness, but could not bear to destroy their limbs, so he saved them.
The king then severely whipped them and expelled them outside the capital.
From then on, the people above and below were awed, and all sought to believe and serve. He then held a great assembly and ordained people to live in the temples.
It transforms evil minds and guides the deluded customs, reaching such a state.

When the new king was established, the Dharma Master asked for attendants and provisions, wishing to proceed south to the country of Brahmins.
